Review 3D MXene architectures as sulfur hosts for high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries Yu-Hong Liu Cao-Yu Wang Si-Lin Yang Fei-Fei Cao Huan Ye ⁎ College of Science, Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan 430070, Hubei, China College of Science Huazhong Agricultural University Wuhan 430070 Hubei China College of Science, Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan 430070, Hubei, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Recent progress of 3D MXene architectures in terms of 2D layered structures, 3D multilayered structures, and 3D spherical structures as sulfur hosts towards Li–S batteries have been fully reviewed. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are one of the most promising energy storage devices because of their high theoretical energy density; however, inherent issues including poor electrical conductivity and severe dissolution of S and its discharged products hinder their practical applications. MXenes have metallic conductivity, ultra-thin two-dimensional (2D) structures, rich surface functional groups, and macrostructural adjustability and have been widely used to design advanced sulfur hosts. 3D network structures assembled by 2D MXene nanosheets have shown superior performance for improving reaction kinetics, accommodating and dispersing sulfur at the micro-/nanoscale, and capturing polysulfides due to their porous interconnected structure. Herein, the applications of MXene architectures related to 2D layered structures, 3D multilayered structures, and 3D spherical structures as sulfur hosts are reviewed. The structure-performance relationship, challenges for current designs, and opportunities for future 3D architectures for LSBs are also analyzed. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Cathodes Sulfur hosts MXenes 3D architectures 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) were first developed in the 19th century and are now widely used in portable devices [1]; however, the theoretical capacity of the graphite anode is extremely low and does not meet the requirements of high energy storage applications, especially for electric vehicles and other industries [2,3]. Rechargeable lithium metal batteries based on a lithium metal anode are promising energy storage devices, with a theoretical capacity of 3860 mA h g−1 and a minimum potential of −3.04 V [4–6]. When they are matched with a sulfur cathode with an ultrahigh theoretical capacity (1675 mA h g−1), the theoretical energy density of the constructed LSBs reaches 2600 W h kg−1, which is expected to promote the development of large-scale power grids and power vehicles [7–10]; however, some inherent defects of sulfur cathodes impede the development of high-energy LSBs [11–13]. First, the poor intrinsic electronic conductivity of sulfur and its discharge products (S: 5 × 10−30 S cm−1 at 25 °C; Li2S: 10−13 S cm−1) leads to slow electron migration, low active substance utilization, and poor reaction kinetics [14]. Second, volume expansion due to the conversion of S and Li2S is close to 80% during discharge, which may result in electrical disconnection and the detachment of active materials. Third, discharge intermediates (lithium polysulfides) can dissolve in the electrolyte and give rise to a severe shuttle effect, leading to a low Coulombic efficiency and low sulfur utilization. In addition, the dissolved polysulfides can diffuse through the separator and reach the Li anode to form insulating reductive products that deteriorate the performance of the Li anode. To solve the problems with sulfur cathodes, various strategies including designing reasonable hosts [15], constructing functional separators [16,17], and optimizing the electrolyte [18,19] have been developed to improve the performance of LSBs. Among them, the design of sulfur hosts has become the most promising and widely studied strategy. In early research, sulfur/carbon composite cathodes were constructed by introducing high-conductivity porous carbon matrixes [20–23]. The porous structure can disperse sulfur species at the nano-/microscale, physically block polysulfides, and buffer significant volume changes in sulfur; however, these S/C composite cathodes often demonstrate poor cycling stability, especially at high sulfur loadings, due to weak interactions between the non-polar carbon materials and lithium polysulfides [24,25]. Hence, numerous polar materials such as heteroatom-doped (such as N [26–28], B and P [29]) carbon materials, metal oxides and sulfides [30,31], metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [32], and MXenes [33,34], have been developed as novel sulfur hosts. Later, materials with high catalytic activity such as Au [35], Pt [36], Co [37], metal nitrides [38]/phosphides [39], and sulfides [40] were used to accelerate the conversion reaction kinetics between S and Li2S. Transition-metal carbides and carbonitrides, referred to MXenes, are two-dimensional (2D) materials featuring high electronic conductivity, abundant surface functional groups, structure controllability, and affinity for sulfur. They integrate multiple-in-one advantages in terms of fast transport kinetics, confinement on polysulfides, and small volume changes. They are generally obtained by selectively etching the “A” layer in the laminated “MAX” phase. The general formula is M n +1AX n (n = 1–4), where “M” represents a transition metal, “A” usually represents a group III A or IV A element (such as Al, Ga, Si, or Ge), and “X” represents carbon and/or nitrogen [41,42]. Different types of MXene series have been obtained by HF or in situ formation of HF etching [43,44], electrochemical etching [45], alkali etching [46], and molten salt etching [47]. Due to the metallic nature of transition metal carbides, delaminated Ti3C2T x exhibits an electrical conductivity of 1 × 104 S cm−1, which is substantially higher than that of graphite (1.04 S cm−1) and 1T MoS2 (10–100 S cm−1) [48]. The high electrical conductivity of MXenes can promote rapid electron transfer and sulfur conversion. The intrinsic terminal metal sites of MXenes can strongly anchor to lithium polysulfides through metal-sulfur interactions [49]. Moreover, the many polar functional groups (–O, –OH, and –F) on its surface can prevent the dissolution of polysulfides through polar-polar interactions; however, these same interactions also make 2D MXene nanosheets prone to restacking, giving rise to the lateral long-distance transport of ions and a reduction in the number of active sites and surface chemisorption capacity. These significantly deteriorate the performance of LSBs [50]. In this context, 3D MXene architectures have been developed to suppress the stacking of MXenes and improve the electrochemical performance of batteries. The strategies to transform 2D structures into 3D frameworks include self-assembly [51], sacrificial templates [52], intercalation agents [53], and 3D printing [54]. Compared with their 2D MXene counterparts, 3D MXenes show unique structural superiority related to their high conductivity, low density, abundant active sites, and high specific surface area (Fig. 1 ) [55,56]. Their continuous 3D network structure provides efficient electron pathways and short ion diffusion distances, which facilitate rapid reaction kinetics and high utilization of active sulfur. The porous structure can accommodate and disperse sulfur at the micro-/nanoscale. Moreover, the porous structure can serve as a liquid electrolyte container, enabling sufficient contact between sulfur and the electrolyte. Due to the structural flexibility and stability of 3D MXenes, 3D MXene-based electrodes can buffer volume changes that occur in electroactive sulfur during cycling. Furthermore, 3D MXenes with a high specific surface area can expose abundant active sites, enhancing their ability to adsorb soluble polysulfides and alleviate the shuttle effect. Through the elaborate design of 3D MXene architectures, the Coulombic efficiency, capacity retention, long-term cycling stability, and rate capability of LSBs can be significantly improved. Due to their high conductivity, high specific surface area, fast ion transport, and ability to strongly capture lithium polysulfides, 3D MXene architectures have been used as advanced sulfur hosts to extend the cycle life of LSBs. Herein, we summarize the sulfur cathodes hosted in various 3D MXene architectures. The relationship between the structures and electrochemical performance is carefully investigated. In addition, some challenges related to the current architectures are proposed. Finally, we provide an outlook on the opportunities for future MXene-based long-lifetime LSBs. 2 Two-dimensional (2D) MXene/S composite cathodes The poor electronic conductivity of sulfur and its discharge products, the significant volume change during cycling, and the severe dissolution of intermediate polysulfides all lead to a low Coulombic efficiency and poor cycle lifetime of LSBs. The reasonable design of sulfur hosts is expected to solve these issues. 2D nanomaterials show potential applications due to their high electronic conductivity, large surface area, high integration density, and mechanical flexibility [57,58]. Of these materials, 2D MXenes with unique surface characteristics have attracted widespread attention. First, the high electronic conductivity and the abundant surface functional groups of 2D MXenes can afford rapid electron transfer and enable the strong adsorption of lithium polysulfides [59]. Second, the high film-forming property of 2D MXenes can circumvent the use of inactive components including binders, conductive agents, and current collectors, thus improving a battery’s gravimetric energy density [60]. Third, 2D MXenes are usually ultra-thin, which expose a large number of defects and rich edges to the electrolyte, which can improve polysulfides capture. The edges of a 2D material can even change the electron transfer paths, allowing them to be used as electrocatalysts for sulfur cathodes; thus, various 2D MXene architectures have been developed as sulfur hosts. For instance, the MXene family obtained by etching and removing an intermediate layer presented an accordion-like appearance with few or multiple layers (Fig. 2 a) [61]. The voids of the layered Ti3C2 MXene (L-Ti3C2) served as storage containers (Fig. 2b) for sulfur and the obtained cathode demonstrated a high initial specific capacity and a low capacity decay; however, the constructed MXene/sulfur cathode showed poor cycling performance due to the open layered structure of the accordion-like MXene. Hence, a surface coating was utilized to suppress polysulfide dissolution. Yu et al. reported polydopamine-coated MXene nanosheets (Mxe@PDA) to realize the dual confinement of polysulfides (Fig. 2c) [62]. The S@Mxe@PDA cathode demonstrated excellent cycling stability at a sulfur loading of 4.4 mg cm−2. Nevertheless, due to its stacked structure, the accordion-like MXene showed limited active sites and storage space; thus, the prepared MXene/S cathode exhibited a low sulfur loading and severe polysulfide dissolution. In this context, delaminated Ti2C MXene nanosheets (d-Ti2C) were used as sulfur hosts by Nazar and co-workers in 2015 (Fig. 2d) [63]. Due to the strong interactions between the outer inherent Ti atoms in MXene and polysulfide species, the S/Ti2C composite exhibited stable long-term cycling performance (Fig. 2e). Subsequently, Nazar et al. proposed thiosulfate/polysulfate dual-protective barriers to inhibit polysulfide diffusion via an in-situ reaction between hydroxyl groups on the MXene surface and polysulfides (Fig. 2f) [64]. Inspired by this work, various follow-up studies on the use of MXenes in LSBs were reported. Zhang et al. fabricated a thin freestanding S/MXene (S@Ti3C2T x ) film by evenly dispersing sulfur nanoparticles on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets followed by vacuum filtration (Fig. 2g) [65]. Due to electrostatic interactions of the surface functional groups, sulfur-anchored MXene nanosheets formed a 2D layered structure through layer-by-layer self-assembly (Fig. 2h); however, many impurities such as reactants, solvents, and byproducts may also be restrained in the 2D MXene/S cathode due to their stacked structure, which may deteriorate the battery’s performance. Later, Ti3C2T x /S conductive paper was prepared through simple vapor deposition [66]. MXenes undoubtedly improve the electrochemical performance of LSBs, but, numbers of fluorine terminal groups on the surface of MXenes greatly weaken the ability to capture and catalyze polysulfides. Moreover, functional groups facilitate the formation of hydrogen bonds, giving rise to the restacking of MXenes, which is not conducive to the access of ions and electrolytes. A self-supporting film assembled from a bare MXene displayed poor mechanical properties due to sliding between 2D nanosheets, which destroyed the integrity of the structure. Recently, Wei et al. prepared a Ti3C2@CF sulfur host by wrapping carbon fibers (CFs) with isolated 2D ultra-thin Ti3C2 nanosheets (Fig. 2i) [67]. Ti3C2@CF-S cathodes showed better mechanical strength and a higher Young's modulus than CF-S cathodes (Fig. 2j), which helped them withstand stress and deformation caused by volume expansion. The Ti3C2@CF-S cathodes displayed a high capacity of 1041.1 mA h g−1 at 0.5C after 200 cycles. Metal oxides, such as V2O5 [68], TiO2 [69], MnO2 [70], ZnO [71], and SnO2 [72], have been utilized to capture lithium polysulfides due to their strong polarity. Of these, TiO2 shows superior non-toxicity, environmentally friendliness, low-cost, and facile preparation. For example, Zhu et al. prepared an MXene nanohybrid composed of dispersed TiO2 quantum dots (TiO2 QDs@MXene) via a simple one-step method [73]. The TiO2 QDs suppressed the restacking of MXene nanosheets, which maintained their 2D lamellar structure (Fig. 3 a). Due to their strong polarity, the TiO2 QDs showed higher binding energy with lithium polysulfides than their Ti3C2T x counterparts (Fig. 3b). As a result, the TiO2 QDs@MXene/S cathode showed significantly improved long-term cycling performance (680 mA h g−1 was delivered at 2C after 500 cycles) and rate capability (663 mA h g−1 at 5C). Later, they designed an MXene@TiO2 nanoarray without sacrificing its structural integrity or intrinsic properties and achieved excellent sulfur encapsulation [74]. However, electrons are hindered from being transferred from the conductive to semi-conductive sides (TiO2) during discharge/charge. This leads to the accumulation of lithium polysulfide on the surface of TiO2, which greatly reduces the reaction kinetics and conversion efficiency. This is extremely unfavorable to the rate performance and cycle stability of the battery. It is thus desirable to find a conductor/semiconductor that possesses a matched bandgap to form heterojunctions with polar compounds/substrates. Shao et al. demonstrated that MXene nanosheets could connect carbon substrates and TiO2 by serving as “band bridges” to acquire rapid mass transfer and redox reaction (Fig. 3c) [75]. Due to the great difference in the Fermi level between them, electrons were redistributed at the interfaces. The electronic conductivity of TiO2 was greatly enhanced, which improved its electrocatalytic activity. The fabricated TM-CNFs hosts displayed excellent cycling stability (723.3 mA h g−1 at 1C after 500 cycles) and a high areal capacity and energy density (10.85 mA h cm−2 and 1909.86 W h kg−1 at a sulfur area loading of 10.5 mg cm−2). Recently, TiO2 nanocrystalline particles [76] or TnQDs (≈3.3 nm) quantum dots with high-concentration OVs (≈20%) [77] derived from MXenes have been used as sulfur hosts, expanding the applications of MXenes. Nevertheless, the application of metal oxides still faces challenges. First, due to their rigidity, metal oxides may weaken the flexibility of MXene. Second, some metal oxides may weaken the conductivity of the entire electrode. Third, the introduction of inactive metal oxides may lower the battery’s gravimetric energy density. Hence, Ti3C2 MXene nanodots were used to replace metal oxides to prevent MXene restacking (Fig. 3d) [78]. The uniform dispersion of high-density ultra-fine Ti3C2T x nanodots (TCD) on the surface of Ti3C2T x nanosheets (TCS) greatly reduced their interfacial resistance and promoted the redox kinetics of sulfur species. The TCD-TCS/S electrode exhibited an ultra-high volumetric capacity (1957 mA h cm−3) even at a high sulfur loading of 13.8 mg cm−2 (Fig. 3e). In summary, 2D sulfur hosts constructed from MXenes show significantly enhanced electrochemical performance, but some defects also remain. First, 2D MXene substrates generally show a low pore volume, which contributes to a relatively low sulfur loading. Second, 2D MXenes may suffer from restacking due to electrostatic interactions between layers, which hinders ion transport. Because of the restacking of 2D MXenes, the specific surface area and the number of active sites will be significantly reduced, which may weaken their ability to adsorb polysulfides. Third, the long lateral distances caused by the 2D lamellar structure retards lithium ion migration, resulting in poor reaction kinetics [79]; therefore, it is necessary to construct 3D MXene architectures that have lightweight, interconnected structures with a high pore volume to address the issues plaguing 2D MXenes. 3 Three-dimensional (3D) MXene/S composite cathodes Compared with 2D MXene materials, 3D network structures have superior sulfur storage and polysulfide immobilization abilities. The 3D network structures formed by 2D MXene subunits [80] show high pore volumes, which facilitates a high sulfur loading and the encapsulation of polysulfides. The interconnected structure of 3D MXenes can prevent the restacking of MXene sheets and thus enable rapid lithium ion transport [81]. Due to their higher surface area, more polar functional groups of 3D MXenes will be exposed to electrolytes, which enhances its binding with polysulfides. In this context, various 3D MXene architectures, such as 3D multilayer structures, 3D hollow structures, and 3D microsphere structures have been developed as sulfur hosts. 3.1 3D multilayered structures 3D multilayered structures inherit the advantages of 2D nanosheets. Compared with stacked 2D nanosheets, each nanosheet in the multilayered structure is separated by the intercalated species. Due to the extended distance, the multilayered structure has a greater exposes much more surface area and storage space. Hence, a high sulfur loading and good confinement of polysulfides are achieved for multilayered structures. Moreover, multilayered structures can prevent the restacking of MXene nanosheets, enabling fast lithium ion transport. For example, Wang et al. fabricated a sandwich-like Ti3C2 MXene/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) hybrid host by plating rGO into MXene nanosheets (Fig. 4 a and b) [82]. Due to the synergistic effects of MXenes and rGO, the MXene/rGO/S cathode demonstrated a high initial capacity of 1144.2 mA h g−1 at 0.5C and a high retention capacity of 878.4 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles with a 70% sulfur loading (Fig. 4c); however, due to low polarity of rGO, it generally shows poor binding with polar polysulfides. Hence, Guo et al. reported an octahedral 1 T phase MoS2 with excellent electrical conductivity and positively-charged S-vacancies (Vs) (Fig. 4d and e) [83]. Through strong interactions between the positively-charged Vs defects and polysulfides, the shuttle effect was largely suppressed, and the material showed a long-term cycle performance of 300 cycles at 0.5C (Fig. 4f). Engineering heterostructures such as TiO2/TiN [84], MoN/VN [85], and ZnS/FeS [86] composed of various coupling components with different bandgaps can promote charge carrier transport and interfacial reaction kinetics, thus boosting the efficiency of the trapping-diffusion-conversion process. For instance, a twinborn TiO2-TiN heterostructure was designed to facilitate the conversion of polysulfides. A ZnS-FeS heterostructure with a large intrinsic energy bandgap was employed to improve the catalytic activity. To accommodate sulfur, a 2D layered MXene with an affinity for polysulfides due to strong interfacial Ti-S interactions was developed to accommodate sulfur, but its planar surface led to a low sulfur loading and poor diffusion kinetics. Hence, MXene-based heterostructures including MXene-WS2, MXene-COFs, and mesoporous carbon@MXene@carbon have been developed as sulfur hosts. One groundbreaking work of 2D MoS2-on-MXene heterostructures was first reported by Gogotsi and co-workers through the in-situ sulfidation of Mo2TiC2T x MXene [87]. Later, an MXene-C3N4 heterostructure was designed to improve the Li+ reaction kinetics and the corresponding electrochemical cycling stability [88]. Recently, Yang et al. built a 2D inorganic–organic heterostructure by the in-situ growth of layered covalent triazine frameworks (COF) on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets as a sulfur host (Fig. 4g) [89]. Due to the formation of a stable interface by the Ti-N interactions between MXenes and COFs (Fig. 4h–i), the prepared sulfur cathode demonstrated fast redox reaction kinetics. Because of the integrity of MXenes and COFs, the composite cathode realized a high sulfur loading of 76%, a high rate capability for over 1000 cycles at 1C, and good cycling performance with a high capacity retention of 94% at a high areal sulfur loading of 5.6 mg cm−2 for 100 cycles. Yamauchi et al. prepared a sandwichlike carbon@MXene@carbon mesoporous heterostructure via micelle-directed interfacial assembly [90]. By using it as a sulfur host, the heterostructured MXene@C/S cathode demonstrated a favorable rate capability (828 mA h g−1 at 2C) and long-term cycling stability (914 mA h g−1 was delivered at 0.5C after 500 cycles). Liu et al. proposed an asymmetric polar double-sided heterostructure by stacking Ti2C on WS2 and then oxidizing the top surface of the Ti2C [91]. Due to the internal electric field generated by the different polarities on both sides, the heterostructure exhibited a large inherent polarity. The O-terminal side strongly adsorbed lithium polysulfides due to the high adsorption energy while the S-terminal side facilitated the conversion of polysulfides due to its low diffusion and decomposition barriers. Multilayered MXene/S composite architectures with expanded interlayer spacings can prevent the stacking of layers, realize high sulfur loadings, and show good confinement of polysulfides; however, their practical applications are hindered by the non-directional and uneven interlayer spacing and harsh synthesis conditions. Moreover, most multilayer structures present open systems that cannot completely block the dissolution of polysulfides during long-term cycling. 3.2 3D porous structures Hollow structures generally have large internal cavities, a strong shell, and interconnected brackets. Large internal cavities can store large amounts of sulfur, while the strong shell acts as a physical barrier that restrains polysulfide diffusion. In addition, internal cavities can alleviate stress arising from volume expansion and contraction during lithiation/delithiation. For instance, Wang et al. fabricated highly-crumpled nitrogen-doped MXene nanosheets that feature high pore volume and high adsorption capacity by thermally annealing negatively-charged MXene nanosheets and positively-charged melamine (Fig. 5 a and b) [92]. The nitrogen-doped MXene nanosheets/sulfur cathode enabled long-term cycling stability (1000 cycles at 2C) at a high sulfur loading of 5.1 mg cm−2. A self-supported MXene film (Fig. 5c) composed of MXene hollow microspheres obtained high lithium [93]/sodium [94] storage. Sun et al. fabricated a porous N-doped Ti3C2 MXene (P-NTC) with uniform pore size (~300 nm) through the self-assembly of MXene nanosheets and melamine formaldehyde microspheres followed by thermal annealing (Fig. 5d and e) [95]. Due to the improved chemical capture and catalytic conversion of P-NTC toward polysulfides, the prepared S/P-NTC cathode displayed a low capacity decay of only 0.033% per cycle for 1200 cycles at 2C. Recently, Wu et al. constructed a self-standing 3D nanoribbons/sulfur cathode (Fig. 5f) [96]. The nanoribbons formed an interconnected macroporous structure, which facilitated a high sulfur storage and fast lithium-ion diffusion. In addition, the self-standing cathode avoided the use of conventional Al current collectors, which enhanced the composite’s specific capacity and overall energy density of the LSBs. Despite this progress, the MXene microstructures tend to restack due to hydrogen bonds between layers. Aimed at solving this issue, lightweight carbonaceous materials with large specific surface areas and large pore volumes were introduced to prevent the re-stacking of MXenes. Wang et al. prepared an MXene@mesoporous carbon hybrid architecture that integrated the advantages of MXenes and porous carbon (Fig. 6 a) [97]. The Ti3C2 MXene containing rich functional groups helped capture sulfur and lithium polysulfides, while the mesoporous carbon framework realized a high sulfur loading and helped alleviate significant volume expansion. Hence, the prepared hybrid S cathode exhibited a prolonged lifespan of over 300 cycles at 0.5C. Sun et al. fabricated a composite sulfur host (denoted as HPCSs@d-Ti3C2) through the electrostatic self-assembly of hollow carbon spheres and MXenes [98]. The composite of HPCSs and d-Ti3C2 encapsulated sulfur and fixed polysulfide. In addition, 1D polyethyleneimine (PEI)-functionalized CNTs were introduced to prevent the aggregation and restacking of MXene nanosheets (Fig. 6b) [99]. Due to strong electrostatic interactions between the negatively-charged MXene and the positively-charged CNT-PEI, a porous MXene architecture with a 3D percolating network and enhanced surface area was obtained (Fig. 6c). Wang et al. fabricated a unique 3D porous Ti3C2T x MXene/rGO (MX/G) hybrid aerogel as a polysulfide reservoir, which achieved fast ion/electron conduction and strong chemical anchoring of polysulfides [100]. Recently, heteroatoms with catalytic activity were used to improve polysulfides adsorption and cathode kinetics. For instance, an MXene-based Co, N-codoped porous carbon nanosheets/sulfur (MCoNPCNSs/S) cathode exhibited a high electrochemical activity by delivering a high initial capacity of 1340.2 mA h g−1 at 0.2C [101]. Zhao et al. prepared a hollow Co-CNT@MXene host by the in-situ growth of ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 nanoparticles on hollow MXene microspheres [102]. The hollow Co-CNT@MXene with a hierarchical structure and large interior porosity (Fig. 6d and e) ensured mass transport (Fig. 6g) and a high sulfur storage for 6 mg cm−2. The embedded cobalt (Fig. 6f) uniformly dispersed onto the conductive carbon nanotubes accelerated the sulfur species conversion kinetics (Fig. 6h and i); therefore, the hollow Co-CNT@MXene/S cathode exhibited an excellent rate capability and long cycling stability (900 mA h cm−2 for 840 cycles at 1C). 3D hollow MXene-based composites are effective for storing sulfur and buffering volume changes, and have been developed as potential sulfur hosts; however, 3D hollow MXene-based composites generally suffer from cracking due to their poor mechanical properties, which are not conducive to large-scale production. Moreover, sulfur may aggregate and form micron-sized particles in macroporous structures due to poor dispersion, leading to low sulfur utilization and poor dynamic kinetics. Loose and porous 3D MXene frameworks promote the absorption of large amounts of electrolyte. Superfluous electrolyte accelerates the dissolution of polysulfides, contributing to a low Coulombic efficiency and poor cycling performance. Compared with hollow spheres, solid spheres have a higher mechanical strength and tap density. Hence, a series of MXene architectures including ball-like MXenes and flower-like MXenes have been constructed to increase the structural stability and gravimetric energy density of batteries. For example, our group fabricated an ultra-strong, self-supporting, and ultrathin MXene film composed of topological microsphere structures via a facile spin steam technology (Fig. 7 a and b) [103]. A composite Li anode based on an MXene film demonstrated high stability for over 1300 h at 0.5 mA cm−2. Wu et al. prepared N‑Ti3C2@CNT interwoven microspheres (Fig. 7c) through the nickel-induced in-situ growth of CNTs combined spray drying [104]. The N‑Ti3C2@CNT microspheres/S cathode demonstrated long-term cycling stability (capacity decay rate of only 0.016% per cycle after 1000 cycles at 1C) (Fig. 7d); however, due to their dense and compact structures, MXene hosts usually exhibit a low porosity, which is not suitable for high sulfur loadings. In addition, they suffer from poor kinetics due to limited transport pathways. Hence, Liang et al. constructed an interwoven KB/S@Ti3C2T x cathode through the self-assembly of negatively-charged MXene nanosheets and positively-charged Ketjen black/sulfur (KB/S) particles [105]. The KB/S@Ti3C2T x cathode delivered a high reversible capacity of 810 mA h cm−2 with a high areal capacity of 6.4 mA h cm−2 and high sulfur areal loading of 5.6 mg cm−2 at 0.2C. Wang et al. reported a high tap density, polarity, and conductive flower-like electrode system (FLPT) by the self-assembly of Ti3C2 MXene (Fig. 7e) [106]. Each flower-like structure was composed of curved nanosheets oriented at different angles (Fig. 7f). The synthesized FLPT-S electrode delivered a high areal capacity of 10.04 mA h cm−2 and an ultra-high volumetric capacity of 2009 mA h cm−3 (Fig. 7g); however, polar MXenes may demonstrate only a limited ability to prevent the shuttle effect, which is detrimental to a battery’s long-term stable cycling. To improve polysulfide adsorption, polar atoms were introduced into microsphere architectures. For instance, Wu et al. prepared a composite S cathode by integrated S@TiO2 nanospheres and MXene layers [107]. The as-obtained S cathode showed improved initial discharge specific capacity and rate capability due to the high conductivity of MXene layers and the encapsulation and adsorption of TiO2 for active sulfur. Yang et al. implanted single-atom zinc into an MXene to accelerate the redox reactions of sulfur by reducing the energy barrier (Fig. 8 a) [108]. Due to ability of SA-Zn-MXene to confine sulfur (Fig. 8b), the S@SA-Zn-MXene cathode exhibited significantly increased sulfur utilization by showing a high initial capacity of 1200 mA h g−1 and favorable rate capability (640 mA h g−1 at 6C). Nevertheless, these single catalysts cannot meet multiple requirements such as strong polysulfide adsorption, rapid electron transfer kinetics, and high catalytic activity for the conversion of polysulfides. Hence, Chen et al. improved polysulfide adsorption and catalytic conversion by applying surface strain regulation [109]. The enlarged Ti-Ti bond arising from the exerted internal stress on the surface facilitated polysulfide transformation into Li2S (Fig. 8c and d). The constructed MXene/CNT porous microsphere with an interconnected framework restricted the dissolution of sulfur and also maintained structural stability (Fig. 8e); therefore, the MXene/CNT/S cathode demonstrated a high sulfur activity with an initial capacity of 1451 mA h g−1 at 0.2C, a maximum rate of 8C, and a cycle life of over 500 cycles at 1C. Self-assembled 3D MXene microsphere architectures show their superior structures for improving electrode stability and the volumetric energy density of batteries; however, due to their limited porosity, 3D MXene/S microsphere cathodes generally demonstrate a low sulfur loading and poor transport kinetics, resulting in a low gravimetric energy density and poor rate capability; therefore, it is necessary to find a balance between the porosity and tap density. 4 Conclusions and outlook LSBs have emerged as promising electrochemical energy storage devices due to their high theoretical energy density, but their poor electronic conductivity, dissolution of sulfur, and the discharge products of polysulfides limit their practical applications. Designing sulfur hosts is an effective strategy for addressing the above issues. 2D MXenes show superior abilities to realize efficient trapping–diffusion–conversion of polysulfides due to their intrinsic structural characteristics of high conductivity, abundant surface functional groups, structure maneuverability, and catalysis. 3D MXene architectures can provide efficient electron pathways, shorten ion diffusion distances, and provide sufficient space to accommodate sulfur, buffer huge electrode volume changes, and provide abundant active sites for polysulfide absorption. This review focused on the recent progress in the design of MXene architectures including 2D nanosheets, 3D multilayered structures, and 3D spherical structures and their applications for LSBs. 2D MXene nanosheets can evenly disperse sulfur on their surface and effectively capture polysulfides via interactions between polar functional groups and polysulfides. However, hydrogen bonds in MXene nanosheets may facilitate their restacking, giving rise to low sulfur loadings, slow ion transport kinetics, and inferior polysulfide adsorption. Alternatively, 3D MXene architectures have several advantages over 2D layered structures because of their expanded surface area, interwoven channels, and excellent structural and mechanical stability. 3D multilayered structures in which the nanosheets are separated by intercalated species showed enlarged interlayer spacings, which allows for a higher sulfur loading and better confinement of polysulfides. Unfortunately, 3D multilayered structures generally present open structures, which cannot effectively block the dissolution of polysulfides during long-term cycling. The further developed 3D hollow structures with large internal voids and strong shells can store and restrict sulfur, but sulfur particles inside tend to aggregate into large particles and exhibit a low electrochemical activity. Moreover, 3D hollow structures are fragile, which results in poor electrode structural stability and cycling stability. 3D spherical MXenes with dense structures show high mechanical strength and high tap density, but their relatively low porosity and weak catalytic ability contribute to a low sulfur loading and poor reaction kinetics. The combination of the merits of the above structures provides a new direction for future research to achieve a multiple-in-one performance requirement, regarding fast transport kinetics, high sulfur loadings, well polysulfide confinement, small volume changes, and high gravimetric/volumetric energy densities. 3D MXenes with hierarchical structures that integrate high pore volume, high specific surface, and high mechanical property may be developed as one feasible future direction. In addition, surface/interfacial engineering is recommended to controllably regulate the surface properties of MXenes to increase their sulfur capture ability and catalytic activity. For instance, oxygen-functionalized and sulfur-functionalized MXenes show strong capture and catalytic conversion for polysulfides. In addition, numerous research efforts should be devoted to exploring the reaction mechanism to help design suitable architectures. So, advanced characterization techniques, such as in-situ imaging, theoretical calculations, and COMSOL Multiphysics simulations should be used to support mechanistic analyses. Finally, low-cost, environmental-friendly, safe, and high-yield methods are applied for the large-scale preparation of MXenes to meet practical application requirements. MXenes also show their application potential in separator and Li anode. MXenes with the high electronic conductivity and strong affinity for polysulfides have been designed as interlayer materials or expanded sulfur hosts between cathode and separator to accelerate sulfur conversion and capture polysulfides. As an interfacial layer or host for Li anode, its high specific surface area helps reduce local current density, realizing uniform Li+ flux. The abundant surface polar functional groups anchored on the surface of MXene sheets show a fine affinity to Li, guiding uniform nucleation and growth of Li metal as well as stabilizing the Li/electrolyte interface. MXenes with the 3D interconnected network structures can accommodate high areal capacity of Li, free from large volume change, maintaining stable electrode volume. In the future, all-MXene-based LSBs can be expected to improve their overall electrochemical performances. Her research focuses on advanced nanocomposite cathode materials and lithium metal anode for rechargeable lithium batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are one of the most promising energy storage devices because of their high theoretical energy density; however, inherent issues including poor electrical conductivity and severe dissolution of S and its discharged products hinder their practical applications. MXenes have metallic conductivity, ultra-thin two-dimensional (2D) structures, rich surface functional groups, and macrostructural adjustability and have been widely used to design advanced sulfur hosts. 3D network structures assembled by 2D MXene nanosheets have shown superior performance for improving reaction kinetics, accommodating and dispersing sulfur at the micro-/nanoscale, and capturing polysulfides due to their porous interconnected structure. Herein, the applications of MXene architectures related to 2D layered structures, 3D multilayered structures, and 3D spherical structures as sulfur hosts are reviewed. The structure-performance relationship, challenges for current designs, and opportunities for future 3D architectures for LSBs are also analyzed.
